title.text: Proceedings of the 2nd Workshop on Computational Linguistics and Clinical Psychology: From Linguistic Signal Beyond LDA: Exploring Supervised Topic Modeling for Depression-Related Language in Twitter

abstractContent.text: Topic models can yield insight into how depressed and non-depressed individuals use language differently.
In this paper, we explore the use of supervised topic models in the analysis of linguistic signal for detecting depression , providing promising results using several models.

introductionContent.text: Depression is one of the most prevalent forms of mental illness: in the U.S. alone, 25 million adults per year suffer a major depressive episode, and observe that " 2020, depression is projected to be among the most important contributors to the global burden of disease".

Unfortunately, there are significant barriers to obtaining help for depression and mental disorders in general, including potential stigma associated with actively seeking treatment () and lack of access to qualified diagnosticians.
When patients suffering from depression see a primary care physician, the rates of misdiagnosis are staggering).
These considerations have helped to motivate a recent surge of interest in finding accessible, cost effective, non-intrusive methods to detect depression and other mental disorders.

Continuing a line of thought pioneered by Pennebaker and colleagues, and others), researchers have been developing methods for identifying relevant signal in people's language use, which could potentially provide inexpensive early detection of individuals who might require a specialist's evaluation, on the basis of their naturally occurring linguistic behavior, e.g. (. Critical mass fora community of interest on these topics has been building within the computational linguistics research community).

To date, however, the language analysis methods used in this domain have tended to be fairly simple, typically including words or n-grams, manually defined word categories (e.g., Pennebaker's LIWC lexicon,), and "vanilla" topic models ().

This stands in contrast to other domains of computational social science in which more sophisticated models have been developed for sometime, including opinion analysis, analysis of the scientific literature (, and computational political science.

In this paper, we take steps toward employing more sophisticated models in the analysis of linguistic signal for detecting depression, providing promising results using supervised LDA and supervised anchor topic models ( , and beginning some initial exploration of anew supervised nested LDA model (SNLDA).
